Having Quality Sleep.title: Sleep
suggestions: Create a consistent nightly wind down routine (such as taking a warm bath, drinking caffeine-free tea, dimming the lights, or reading a book)
Keep a consistent sleep schedule throughout the week
Leave the bedroom and do something relaxing if unable to fall asleep after more than 30 minutes of laying in bed
Avoid caffeine six hours before going to sleep
Reduce use of electronics one hour before going to bed
Try a white noise app or machine to maintain a quiet atmosphere when sleeping
Sleep in a dark space

Maintaining Balanced Nutrition.title: Nutrition
suggestions: Use smaller bowls and spoons when eating foods that are high in processed sugar
Consume the skin when eating fruits and vegetables to increase your intake of fiber
Make drinking water a habit; try drinking at least one glass of water each time you complete a daily activity, such as eating a meal or leaving the restroom
Pack a lunch ahead of time because you are more likely to make nutritious choices when you are not excessively hungry
When cooking, make extra food for leftovers
Limit alcohol and drug consumption

Engaging in Physical Movement & Getting.title: Movement
suggestions: Schedule exercise ahead of time to make movement a priority
Take the stairs when possible to incorporate exercise into daily tasks
Stretch while watching television to increase physical movement during leisure activities
Complete errands by foot or bicycle
Take walks during lunch breaks to ensure you get fresh air during your day
Play outside with your children

Developing Time Management Techniques.title: Time
suggestions: Schedule time for breaks, unexpected events, or “just being” with your child
Make a to-do list in order of your most immediate priorities
Create a to-don’t list of things that can be addressed later on
Utilize a virtual calendar app that is shareable between family members
Reach out for help when needed

Practicing Mindfulness.title: Mindfulness
suggestions: Explore a mindfulness app such as Insight Timer, Calm, or Headspace
Keep a journal to write about your experiences, thoughts, and sensations
Practice being present during at least one daily activity (such as while driving, eating breakfast, or washing the dishes)
Set a timer for three minutes and focus on your breath
Practice breathing with a longer exhale than inhale
Try a body scan meditation (notice the sensations in your body, starting from your toes and traveling up to your head)
Try the 5-4-3-2-1 grounding technique (acknowledging five things you can see around you, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste)

Seeking Social Support.title: Support
suggestions: Join a Facebook group for parents that share your child’s diagnosis
Regularly schedule time to speak with a trusted loved one
